attributes.title: Optimism, risk and behaviour in a pandemic's early phases

q2.value:
H1a: “Optimism” will be negatively associated with “Perceived risk”
H1b: Interaction of low “Optimism” and high “Exposure” on “Perceived personal risk”
H1c: “Optimism” will be associated with “risk for others” being seen as larger than “risk for self”
H1d: “Optimism” will be negatively associated with “Compliance”

H2a: “Perceived risk” will be positively associated with “Compliance”
H2b: “Perceived risk” will be positively associated with higher trust in government health advice compared to before the pandemic

H3: “Perceived risk” will be positively associated with “Cautious information gathering”

H4a: “Perceived risk” will be negatively associated with “COVID-19”
H4b: Interaction of low “Perceived risk” and high “Exposure” on “COVID-19”

H5a: “Compliance” will be negatively associated with “COVID-19”
H5b: Interaction of low “Compliance” and high “Exposure” on “COVID-19”

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Cross-sectional online survey to nationally representative sample. Collected as part of a panel design, which allows longitudinal comparison for some items.

q8.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Data was collected using the established "Norwegian Citizen Panel" (see https://www.uib.no/en/citizen/43063/about-panel). The panel does regular surveys of the same participants 3-4 times a year on a number of societal issues for various research projects. An extraordinary data collection was performed between March 20 and 27 of 2020. Online surveys were sent out to about 20.000 potential participants who had previously registered for the panel. The panel is nationally representative on a number of demographic variables.

q11.value: Expected total N = 10.000. A third of these will have answered the questions in this pre-registered analysis.

question.value:
27 of the items in the survey were organizaed into the following variables:

Perceived risk (8 items), Contagion exposure (4 items), Cautious information gathering (2 items), Compliance (4 items), Optimism (5 items), and COVID-19 symptoms (4 items).

Item content can be found in the attached file.

Means of the items will be calculated for each variable (reversing scores for negatively phrased items).

For H1c, the item marked as "ft1cov_psyk15a" will be used for “risk for others”, while the item marked as "ft1cov_psyk2" will be used for “risk for self”.

For H2b, increased trust in health advice will be measured as the difference between R9helse4_1 in the January survey, and ft1cov_psyk12 in the March survey.
Simple and multiple regressions will be used.

q19.value: One-tailed tests against p smaller than .01.

q22.value: Exploratory analyses will test the hypotheses for at-risk subsamples of the total sample,

attributes.title: Master Thesis Charlotte Elisabeth Vaaßen KU LEUVEN

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Master Thesis Project r0689369 KU Leuven, Part 2/3

other.value:
Possible further analyses:

Logit/probit to investigate if D-score can predict if participants score above/below sample average (or population norm) on Big 5 traits,  SECS, or SDO (incl. subscales).


Any changes or additional analyses will be reported and uploaded in OSF.

sample.value:
The data will be collected via opportunity sampling, and via Prolifics, using participants of at least 18 years of age who have completed high school, balancing across gender. 

Target sample size is 40 after excluding possibile outliers, and a maximum of 50 including outliers.

analyses.value:
1. RT calculations: D-score algorithm, following procedure in Callan et al. (2010).

H0: D-score does not differ for associations between legal concepts and rigidity, or legal concepts and flexibility.
H1: D-score  for associations between legal concepts and rigidity, and legal concepts and flexibility differ significantly such that D-scores are higher for associations between law and rigidity, than law and flexibility.

Tested using both frequentist and Bayesian one-sided t-test. 

2.  Predicting D-Score differences (at individual participant level) from participant's SDO, SECS and Big 5 scores

Analysis: either classical frequentist multiple regression or Bayesian hierarchical model, starting with model

D-score (or RT) = b0 + b1SDO + b2SECS + b3Big5_Openness 

H0: none of the IVs has a significant effect on the D-score 

Analysis will be exploratory (include specification tests, changing adding or subtracting subscale measures such as SDO-D, SDO-E) to select the model with the best fit. 

The code for all models will be made available.

outliers.value:
Following Karpinsi and Steinmann (2006), responses that took less than 350 ms will be excluded from the critical blocks used to calculate the D-score.

Overall, participants who finished the study  (inc. SC-IAT, SDO, Big 5 and SECS measures) in less than 5 minutes will in excluded from the analysis.

dependent.value:
Social Dominance Orientation (IV) 
Social and Economic Conservatism Scale (SECS) (IV)
Big 5 44-item measure (IV) 

SC-IAT D-score/reaction times (DV)

conditions.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to two conditions in the SC-IAT.  They will either start with "rigid'' or ''flexible'' word categorizations (counter-balancing). Otherwise the conditions will be identical.

hypothesis.value:
Main questions being asked in this study:


1. Do participants implicitly associate the law (legal concepts) as something that is rigid, rather than  something that is flexible? 

Test if people mentally associate legal concepts  more strongly with rigidity rather than flexibility as indicated by reaction times (D-score) in a Single Category Association Task (Karpinski and Steinmann, 2006). 

2. Moreover, is this possible association  influenced by specific personality traits (e.g. openness), or socio-economic attitudes (conservatism, liberalism)?

Test if variation in D-scores can be explained by individual differences in SDO, SECS, Big5 (and subscales) using multiple regression models (exploratory analysis).

attributes.title: Rotovation
attributes.description:
The aim of this study is to determine the extent to which job rotation can improve the physical and psychosocial work environment, advance gender and social equality among workers, and improve production quality at a commercial laundromat in Sweden. 
The specific aims of the study are to: 
1)	Describe the current physical and psychosocial working environment, including a focus on the division of labour between employees.
2)	Determine the extent to which a job rotation intervention improves the physical and psychosocial working environment for individual workers, and increases gender and social equality within the organisation.
3)   Evaluate the efficacy of the job rotation implementation process.

name.value:
Title: Reversibility: Taste vs. Quality 
Description: The study will examine if the effects of reversibility on satisfaction is moderated by decision frame. Specifically, we predict that reversibility affects satisfaction when decisions are framed in terms of quality, rather than taste.

sample.value: 400 observations would be collected so that there are 100 observations per condition.

analyses.value: Planned contrasts between reversible and irreversible conditions in the quality condition as well as taste condition.

outliers.value: Participants who failed all attention checks would be removed from the sample. Those  who failed to indicate "strongly agree" to the question "I took time to carefully read and follow the instructions" and "strongly disagree" to the question " I may have been distracted while filling out the survey.

dependent.value: The key dependent variable will be satisfaction with your chosen option which would be measured on a 7-point Likert scale ranging from 1 = not at all to 7 = extremely.

conditions.value: The study will adopt a 2 (reversibility: irreversible vs. reversible) x 2 (frame: taste vs. quality) between-subjects design, resulting in 4 conditions.  Participants will be randomly assigned to these conditions.

hypothesis.value: When decisions are based on quality, irreversible decisions would elicit greater satisfaction than reversible decisions. When decisions are based on taste. , the effects of decision reversibility on satisfaction would be attenuated.

q2.value: Marvin Paul Liesner, Wilfried Kunde, Christian Böffel, Jochen Müsseler

q3.value: Previous research has shown that taking the perspective of virtual avatars can lead to the occurence of various effects often observed in cognitive psychology not anymore from an egocentric perspective, but rather from the avatar's perspective. For example, it has been shown that vertically presented stimuli in a Simon Task which are spatially neutral for the person performing the task can still evoke a Simon effect when a 90° rotated avatar (from the egocentric perspective) is presented next to the stimuli. The current study will investigate whether this also accounts for an action-effect compatibility effect, thus when participants have to respond to  stimuli by certain movements (e.g., a hand movement to the left or right) which causes object movements which are spatially neutral for the participant, but corresponding to the direction of the hand movement from an avatar's perspective (e.g., vertical object movements with a 90° rotated avatar). This would be an interesting extension to the current research because the occurence of such a compatibility effect would suggest that humans could remap their body movements into another perspective.

q4.value: We expect faster reaction times for cases where responses to a visual stimulus cause object movements which are action-effect compatible from an avatar's perspective than for cases where they are action-effect incompatible from the avatar's perspective.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Participants will respond to circle-shaped color stimuli which will be presented in the center of the screen. There will be goal boxes above and below the stimulus and a two-dimensional avatar seen from above either on the left or on the right (varied blockwise) of the stimulus facing the stimulus. Based on the color of the stimulus, participants will be asked to move it either to the left or to the right from the avatar's perspective. For every avatar side there will be one block each in which the cursor movement will be achieved by a movement in the corresponding (e.g., right for avatar, right for participant) or non-corresponding (e.g., right for avatar, left for participant) direction of the participant's hand. Order of blocks and stimulus-response mapping are counterbalanced between participants. Trial order is randomized within blocks. At the end of each session, participants will fill our a short questionnaire regarding their experienced ownership of the avatar and their experienced agency for cursor movements.

q9.value: Order of trials  in every block will be randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants can sign up for the study using an online platform specific for that purpose. Participants need to have normal or corrected to normal vision, have no known neurological or psychiatric diseases and be fluent in German in order to understand task instructions.

q14.value: The sample size is based on a pilot study.

question.value:
Compatibility between hand movement (egocentric perspective) and cursor movement (avatar perspective): compatible vs. incompatible (2 levels)
Avatar Side: right/left of cursor (2 levels)

Manipulated variables that will not enter the analyses, but that will be used for counterbalancing reasons and to limit predictability of trials:
- Inter-Stimulus Interval: 1500ms vs. 2500 ms (2 levels)
- Color-Response Mapping: 2 combinations
- Required response: left vs. right (2 levels)

Reaction Time
Movement Time
Ownership experience of the avatar (questionnaire at the end of the experiment)
Sense of agency for cursor movements (questionnaire at the end of the experiment)

Mean reaction times and movement times over all trials in given condition
Ownership scores as sum over ten question
Corrected ownership score as difference between sum of specific ownership questions and general ownership questions

Repeated measures ANOVA with factors compatibility and avatar side on reaction times
Follow-up t-tests to test compatibility effect
t-test against 0 for ownership scores

q21.value:
p value will be set at .05.
One-tailed tests will be conducted because hypotheses are directed.

q22.value: Trials with reaction times below 150 ms or  above 1500 ms will be excluded from analyses. All trials with erroneous responses will be excluded from analyses.

q24.value: RM ANCOVAs might be calculated to test for possible influences of ownership and/or agency scores on the investigated effects. However, this will depend on whether there will be effects on these scores in the first place.

data.value: It's complicated. We have already collected some data but explain in Question 8 why readers may consider this a valid pre-registration nevertheless.

name.value: Exploring habituation to and generalisation for visual size-singletons

other.value: Data collection has begun today, and the data hasn't been looked at. Therefore, we think this can still be a valid pre-registration.

sample.value: We plan to collect usable data from 20 participants. This sample size is based on our previous study (judging by the width of the confidence intervals and compatibility/HPD intervals), and the power analysis conducted for it.

analyses.value:
The data are going to be analysed using the R language and the lme4 and Stan packages. We will fit a mixed effects model with individual reaction times at the lowest level, and with intercepts varying over participants. We will enter the block number, block half, additional singleton (AS) size, the block number x additional singleton size and block half x additional singleton size interactions as predictors. All predictors will be dummy coded, and the reaction times will be standardised with regard to the whole sample. Hence, the model in lmer notation is:

reactionTimeScaled ~ (1 | subId) + blockHalf + blockNumber + scalingFactor + blockHalf : scalingFactor + blockNumber : scalingFactor.

The scalingFactor variable will have 5 levels - 4 for the different scaling factors (0.5, 0.75, 1.25. 1.5) and one for the no-additional-singleton condition. The no-AS condition will serve as baseline.

The statistical significance of the hypotheses will be tested at the .03 alpha level, using the multcomp package.

An equivalent model will be fit using the Stan language, with priors to be determined based on the posterior of a previous study.

outliers.value:
Reaction times for all incorrect responses will be excluded from the analyses. Further, within
each subject, each experimental block, and each additional singleton condition we will
exclude reaction times that are more than ±2.5 SD away from their respective means.
Furthermore, our experiment will include no-go trials designed to motivate fixation. All
subjects that commit errors on more than 20% of go or no-go trials will be excluded from
further analyses.

dependent.value:
The main dependent variable will be reaction times to individual trials expressed in
milliseconds. The participants' task will be to make a simple perceptual decision regarding a
stimulus found within a larger target shape, placed among other distractor shapes. The entire
experimental protocol will be delivered using Matlab software with Psychtoolbox extensions,
and reaction times will be recorded likewise. Subjects will respond using a computer
keyboard and the reaction time is defined as the time interval between the onset of the
stimulus array and the subject's response.

conditions.value:
We will use a within-subjects 2 (additional singleton absent vs. present) x 4 (additional
singleton size scaling factor relative to other stimuli: 0.5, 0.75, 1.25, 1.5) repeated-measures,
experimental design. Trials will be divided into four blocks, each having one of the above
mentioned additional singleton scaling factors. The order of the scaling factors will be
counterbalanced across participants using a latin square scheme. Each of the four
experimental blocks will contain 180 trials. Each trial will consist of (1) a fixation display,
whose duration will be determined by a random draw (with replacement) from an interval
between 1000 and 1250 ms, followed by (2) a display comprising an array of six stimuli
drawn on an imaginary circle around the still visible fixation point. Five of the stimuli will
have one of the two possible colours – red (30.0 cd/m 2 ) or green (30.0 cd/m 2 ). The remaining
stimulus will have the other remaining colour (i.e. red if the other five are green and vice

versa) - this is the target stimulus participants are instructed to look for. The target has an
equal probability of being of either colour. The target also has an equal probability of
appearing in any of the six available locations. Each stimulus will contain a small vertical or
horizontal line at its center. For each trial, three vertical and three horizontal lines will be
distributed randomly among the six available colours. The participants' task is to indicate the
orientation of the line inside the target stimulus. Each trial will be presented until a
participant gives a response or until 3 seconds have passed. In each block, 50% of the trials
will have an additional singleton present. This singleton will differ in size relative to the other
stimuli by one of the four above mentioned scaling factors. Furthermore, for each target
location, the additional singleton has an equal probability of appearing in any of the
remaining locations. Ten percent of trials in each block are randomly assigned to be no-go
trials. These trials will be signaled by the fixation point being replaced by a square 200 ms
before stimulus array onset. Participants will be instructed not to respond to the no-go trials,
but to wait for the trial to end, which will happen after 3 seconds. Before the first
experimental block there will be a practice block containing 60 trials without an additional
singleton. Participants will receive feedback on correct and incorrect responses during the
practice block. During the experimental blocks, participants will receive feedback only if they
fail to respond within 3 seconds or if they respond to a no-go trial.

hypothesis.value:
The main question this study is designed to answer is whether habituation and generalisation
of attentional capture within the visual system are possible when observers use a singleton-
detection visual search mode. We will explore this in the additional singleton paradigm. The
main purpose of this study is to investigate whether and how the magnitude of attentional
capture changes depending on the amount of experience subjects have with the stimuli and
the task. Based on our previous study, the first hypothesis is that attentional capture by an irrelevant singleton (measured
as the difference between average reaction times for trials containing and those missing an
irrelevant singleton) will not diminish within a block of trials. Our second hypothesis is that the
reduction of attentional capture within a block will not generalise across blocks. We expect
that the differences in reaction times between trials containing and those not containing an
irrelevant singleton will remain practically unchanged across blocks that differ in the
singleton's irrelevant feature value.

The scalingFactor variable will have 5 levels - 4 for the different scaling factors (0.5, 0.75, 1.25. 1.5) and one for the no-additional-singleton condition. The no-AS condition will serve as baseline.

The statistical significance of the hypotheses will be tested at the .03 alpha level, using the multcomp package.

An equivalent model will be fit using the Stan language, with priors to be determined based on the posterior of a previous study.
registration_responses.outliers:
Reaction times for all incorrect responses will be excluded from the analyses. Further, within
each subject, each experimental block, and each additional singleton condition we will
exclude reaction times that are more than ±2.5 SD away from their respective means.
Furthermore, our experiment will include no-go trials designed to motivate fixation. All
subjects that commit errors on more than 20% of go or no-go trials will be excluded from
further analyses.
registration_responses.dependent:
The main dependent variable will be reaction times to individual trials expressed in
milliseconds. The participants' task will be to make a simple perceptual decision regarding a
stimulus found within a larger target shape, placed among other distractor shapes. The entire
experimental protocol will be delivered using Matlab software with Psychtoolbox extensions,
and reaction times will be recorded likewise. Subjects will respond using a computer
keyboard and the reaction time is defined as the time interval between the onset of the
stimulus array and the subject's response.
registration_responses.conditions:
We will use a within-subjects 2 (additional singleton absent vs. present) x 4 (additional
singleton size scaling factor relative to other stimuli: 0.5, 0.75, 1.25, 1.5) repeated-measures,
experimental design. Trials will be divided into four blocks, each having one of the above
mentioned additional singleton scaling factors. The order of the scaling factors will be
counterbalanced across participants using a latin square scheme. Each of the four
experimental blocks will contain 180 trials. Each trial will consist of (1) a fixation display,
whose duration will be determined by a random draw (with replacement) from an interval
between 1000 and 1250 ms, followed by (2) a display comprising an array of six stimuli
drawn on an imaginary circle around the still visible fixation point. Five of the stimuli will
have one of the two possible colours – red (30.0 cd/m 2 ) or green (30.0 cd/m 2 ). The remaining
stimulus will have the other remaining colour (i.e. red if the other five are green and vice

versa) - this is the target stimulus participants are instructed to look for. The target has an
equal probability of being of either colour. The target also has an equal probability of
appearing in any of the six available locations. Each stimulus will contain a small vertical or
horizontal line at its center. For each trial, three vertical and three horizontal lines will be
distributed randomly among the six available colours. The participants' task is to indicate the
orientation of the line inside the target stimulus. Each trial will be presented until a
participant gives a response or until 3 seconds have passed. In each block, 50% of the trials
will have an additional singleton present. This singleton will differ in size relative to the other
stimuli by one of the four above mentioned scaling factors. Furthermore, for each target
location, the additional singleton has an equal probability of appearing in any of the
remaining locations. Ten percent of trials in each block are randomly assigned to be no-go
trials. These trials will be signaled by the fixation point being replaced by a square 200 ms
before stimulus array onset. Participants will be instructed not to respond to the no-go trials,
but to wait for the trial to end, which will happen after 3 seconds. Before the first
experimental block there will be a practice block containing 60 trials without an additional
singleton. Participants will receive feedback on correct and incorrect responses during the
practice block. During the experimental blocks, participants will receive feedback only if they
fail to respond within 3 seconds or if they respond to a no-go trial.
registration_responses.hypothesis:
The main question this study is designed to answer is whether habituation and generalisation
of attentional capture within the visual system are possible when observers use a singleton-
detection visual search mode. We will explore this in the additional singleton paradigm. The
main purpose of this study is to investigate whether and how the magnitude of attentional
capture changes depending on the amount of experience subjects have with the stimuli and
the task. Based on our previous study, the first hypothesis is that attentional capture by an irrelevant singleton (measured
as the difference between average reaction times for trials containing and those missing an
irrelevant singleton) will not diminish within a block of trials. Our second hypothesis is that the
reduction of attentional capture within a block will not generalise across blocks. We expect
that the differences in reaction times between trials containing and those not containing an
irrelevant singleton will remain practically unchanged across blocks that differ in the
singleton's irrelevant feature value.

question10b.value:
Prospective respondents will be provided with information about the study before being asked to express their informed consent if they wish to participate. Those who proceed will be directed to the main survey, which will involve respondents being presented with a series of randomly generated descriptions of decision-making processes.

Respondents will be presented with up to ten pairs of decision-making processes – either based on a referendum or a citizens’ assembly (randomly assigned). They will be asked to choose which process they prefer (paired choice), from which process they would be most likely to accept the decision (paired choice), and the extent to which they perceive each process to be realistic (on a 7-point scale).

The 50% of participants who are randomly assigned to evaluate referendums will be presented of 9 pairs of processes: three processes across three categories. The order of the categories will be randomly generated. One category relates to the nature of the political issue: the issue level, issue area, and issue complexity of each process will be randomly generated from the levels specified above. The second category relates to the profile and status of decision-makers: turnout, the size of the majority, and the binding/advisory nature of the decision; again, the level of each attribute will be randomly generated. The third category relates to the political context: the source of the referendum, the duration of the campaign, and the main source of information will vary randomly.

The 50% of participants who are randomly assigned to evaluate mini-publics will be presented of 10 pairs of citizens' assembly processes across three categories. The order of the categories will be randomly generated. The first category relates to the nature of the political issue: the issue level, issue area, and issue complexity of each process will be randomly generated from the levels specified above. The second category relates to the profile and status of decision-makers: the selection mechanism, the size of the majority, the size of the forum, and the binding/advisory nature of the decision; again, the level of each attribute will be randomly generated. The final category relates to the political context: the source of the initiative, the duration of the process, and the main source of information will vary randomly.

Within each category, there is no randomization of the order of attributes within respondents but there is between respondents.

Due to the nature of the study, participants will be aware that the scenarios they are asked to evaluate are randomly generated, and that not all participants will evaluate the same processes.

Respondents have previously indicated that they are willing to be contacted for and participate in online surveys. 1000 participants on this panel will be invited to take part in the study via email. They will be informed about the study before being asked for their informed consent, after which the survey questions are presented to participants; the exercise ends with a debriefing. Respondents from the pilot study will not receive a remuneration. Instead, as is typical for this panel, respondents will receive a short outline of the results. The data will be collected online using Qualtrics.

question6b.value: Approximately 200 respondents will take part. The purpose of this pilot study is to ensure that a diverse, although not representative, sample of participants are able to engage meaningfully with the survey prior to administering it to a representative sample. In particular, we will pay close attention to (1) the time it takes respondents to complete the survey (it should take no more than 15 minutes) and (2) the open-ended responses provided by participants (which can help identify any issues with the complexity of the study). Therefore, for these purposes, we conduct this pilot study on a relatively small non-probability sample.

question7b.value: 1000 members of the University of Antwerp panel will be invited via email to take part in the study. They will have three weeks to complete the survey. Based on previous studies using the panel, we expect to receive 200 responses within this time. The link to the survey will expire after three weeks.

question1a.value:
Hypotheses on *referendum* attributes:
H1a.i. Referendums will be evaluated more positively when they take place on national issues rather than local issues [salience-based argument].
H1a.ii. Referendums will be evaluated more positively when they take place on local issues rather than national issues [proximity-based argument].
H2a. Referendums will be evaluated more positively when they take place on constitutional issues than on economic or moral issues [exploratory hypothesis].
H3a. Referendums will be evaluated more positively when they take place on simple issues rather than complex issues.
H4a. The higher the level of turnout, the more positively citizens evaluate the referendum.
H5a. The bigger the size of the majority voting, the more positively citizens will evaluate the referendum.
H6a. Referendums with a binding outcome are perceived more positively than referendums with advisory decisions.
H7a. Citizen-initiated referendums will be evaluated more positively than government-initiated referendums.
H8a. Referendums with long campaigns are evaluated more positively than referendums with short campaigns.
H9a. Referendums that give independent experts, citizen panels and registered interest groups primary responsibility for information provision will be evaluated more positively than those in which political parties have the primary responsibility for information provision.

Hypotheses on *citizens' assembly* attributes:
H1b. Citizens' assemblies will be evaluated more positively when they take place on local issues rather than national issues.
H2b. Citizens' assemblies will be evaluated more positively when they take place on economic or moral issues than on constitutional issues [exploratory hypothesis].
H3b. Citizens' assemblies will be evaluated more positively when they take place on complex issues rather than simple issues.
H4b. The larger the membership, the more positively citizens evaluate the citizens' assembly.
H5b. Citizens' assemblies with randomly selected members will be evaluated more positively than citizens' assemblies with self-selected members.
H6b. The bigger the size of the majority supporting the recommendation, the more positively citizens will evaluate the citizens' assembly.
H7b. Citizen-initiated citizens' assemblies will be evaluated more positively than government-initiated citizens' assemblies.
H8b. Citizens' assemblies with an advisory outcome are perceived more positively than citizens' assemblies taking binding decisions.
H9b. Citizens' assemblies with long durations are evaluated more positively than citizens' assemblies with short durations.
H10b. Citizens' assemblies that give independent experts primary responsibility for information provision will be evaluated more positively than those in which political parties or advocacy groups have the primary responsibility for information provision.

question2a.value: No interaction effects are formally hypothesised.

question3a.value:
We do not formally include a manipulation check due to the nature of a conjoint experiment: multiple variables are manipulated at once. However, we do ask respondents a series of open-ended questions relating to the manipulated variables:
---
- Do you consider it important or unimportant whether a referendum takes place at the local, regional or national level? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- Do you consider it important or unimportant whether a referendum is about an economic, moral or constitutional issue? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- What issues come to mind when you think of economic issues?
- What issues come to mind when you think of moral issues?
- What issues come to mind when you think of constitutional issues?
- Do you consider it important or unimportant whether a referendum is about a complex or a simple issue? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- Do you consider it important or unimportant that a referendum has a certain level of turnout? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- Do you consider it important or not unimportant that a referendum result has a large or small majority? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- Do you consider it important or not unimportant whether a referendum is treated as advisory or binding? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- Do you consider it important or unimportant that a referendum is initiated by citizens or the government? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- Do you consider it important or not unimportant that a referendum campaign is long (8 weeks) or short (4 weeks)? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- Do you consider it important or not unimportant that the main source of information for voters is from political parties, independent experts, registered interest groups, or a panel of randomly selected citizens? Please briefly explain why you think this.
---
- Do you consider it important or unimportant whether a citizens’ assembly takes place at the local, regional or national level? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- Do you consider it important or unimportant whether a citizens’ assembly is about an economic, moral or constitutional issue? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- What issues come to mind when you think of economic issues?
- What issues come to mind when you think of moral issues?
- What issues come to mind when you think of constitutional issues?
- Do you consider it important or unimportant whether a citizens’ assembly is about a complex or a simple issue? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- Do you consider it important or unimportant that a citizens’ assembly has a large or small number of participants. Please briefly explain why you think this.
- Do you consider it important or unimportant whether citizens’ assembly members are randomly selected or whether anyone can attend? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- Do you consider it important or not unimportant that a citizens’ assembly decision has a large or small majority among its participants? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- Do you consider it important or not unimportant whether a citizens’ assembly decision is treated as advisory or binding? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- Do you consider it important or unimportant that a citizens’ assembly is initiated by citizens or the government? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- Do you consider it important or not unimportant that a citizens’ assembly meets for a long (3 weekends) or a short (1 weekend) period of time? Please briefly explain why you think this.
- Do you consider it important or not unimportant that the main source of information for citizens’ assembly members is from political parties, independent experts, registered interest groups, or a panel drawn from citizens’ assembly members? Please briefly explain why you think this.
---
The primary purpose of asking these open-ended questions is to gain an insight into the thought processes behind participants' responses. In the absence of formal manipulation checks, they also serve as an indication of respondents' engagement with the task.

question1c.value:
*DV1: Process preference*
"Which of these two processes do you prefer? [Process A / Process B]"

*DV2: Decision acceptance*
"From which process would you be most willing to accept the decision? [Process A / Process B]"

*DV3: Perceived fairness*
"Which of these two processes do you think is the fairest? [Process A / Process B]"

Attributes of decision-making processes (IVs) are randomised in paired choice tables. 

*Covariate 1: Perceived realism of each process*
"To what extent do you think [Process A / Process B] was realistic? [1 = Very unrealistic; 7 = Very realistic (+ don't know)]"

*Covariate 2: Satisfaction with democracy*
"On a scale of 0-10, where 0 means not at all satisfied and 10 means completely satisfied, to what extent are you satisfied with how democracy works in the UK? [0 = Not at all satisfied; 10 = Completely satisfied (+ don't know)]"

*Covariate 3: Perceived external efficacy*
"When you think of politics in Northern Ireland, to what extent do you agree or disagree with the following statements?
- Politicians care about the opinion of people like me.
- Politicians in the UK are only interested in my vote and not in my opinion.
- People like me have no influence at all on politics in the UK.
[1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Somewhat disagree; 3 = Neither agree nor disagree; 4 = Somewhat agree; 5 = Strongly agree (+ don’t know)]"

*Covariate 4: Perceived internal efficacy*
"Could you indicate the extent to which you agree with the following statements? 
I feel I understand the most important political issues of this country.
[1 = Strongly disagree; 2 = Somewhat disagree; 3 = Neither agree nor disagree; 4 = Somewhat agree; 5 = Strongly agree (+ don’t know)]"

*Covariate 5: Political interest*
"How interested would you say you are in politics?
[1 = Very interested; 2 = Fairly interested; 3 = Not very interested; 4 = Not at all interested (+ don’t know)"

question2c.value: Average marginal component effects will be estimated using OLS regression.

question3c.value:
Linear regression models will be used to estimate the average marginal component effects of process attributes (IVs) on process preferences, decision acceptance and perceived fairness (DVs).

Models will include covariates for perceived realism of each process, satisfaction with democracy, perceived external efficacy, perceived internal efficacy, political interest, and demographic characteristics (age, sex, education).

question4c.value:
Information equivalence across scenarios is needed to disentangle and estimate the independent effect of each attribute. Including covariates involves ‘‘specifying the values of background attributes in order to prevent respondents from updating about them’’ in order to ‘‘rule out at least some sources of (information equivalence) violations’’ (Dafoe et al., 2018: 401).  This covariate control approach was adopted in a conjoint experiment conducted by Muradova and Gildea (2019). We follow this approach by controlling for relevant background characteristics.

References:
Dafoe A., Zhang, B. and Caughey, D. (2018) 'Information equivalence in survey experiments', Political Analysis 26 (4), pp 399–416.
Muradova, L. and Gildea, R. J. (2019) 'Oil wealth and US public support for war', Conflict Management and Peace Science. DOI: https://doi.org/10.1177/0738894219871655

attributes.title: Creating a Moral Clean Air Zone
attributes.description: This study is exploring the ways in which residents of Bath and NE Somerset perceive and respond to the planned Clean Air Zone and how this might be influenced by different ways of framing and visually presenting the proposal.

q1.value: The impact of moral framing of a clean air zone on driving attitudes and behaviour

q2.value: Annayah Miranda Beatrice Prosser, Dan Thorman, Timothy Robert Kurz

q3.value:
This study will quantitatively explore the question of how the presence of a clean air charging zone might (best) foster a greater sense of moral responsibility amongst drivers; and in turn reduce vehicle use in Bath city centre. The work will build upon past research by the research team demonstrating that people’s psychological and behavioural responses to financial disincentives can be greatly influenced by the way that such measures are framed and communicated (e.g. Kurz et al., 2014; Mulder, 2009; Nelissen & Mulder,2013;  Walker, Kurz & Russel, 2018). Through this study, we will explore how Bath residents’ sense of moral responsibility and motivation to change their transport mode might be influenced by a variety of factors, including
•Physical presence of the ‘Zone’ (operationalised via linage on the road)
•Wording used to describe the scheme/charges (retributive vs compensatory)
•The use of collective (vs individualistic) language when discussing the Zone

q4.value:
H1: We anticipate that framing the introduction of the CAZ using collectivist language (as opposed to individualist) will have the following main effects:
- Decreased intended future car use
- Increased moralisation of the CAZ
- Increased intention to upgrade their vehicle 
- Increased willingness to publicly pledge to reduce their driving
- Increased willingness to influence others 
- Increased support for a more stringent CAZ policy

H2: We anticipate that presenting participants with an artists' impression of the entry to the CAZ that depicts a red marking on the road (as opposed to a road with no physical markings) will have the following main effects:
- Decreased intended future car use
- Increased moralisation of the CAZ
- Increased intention to upgrade their vehicle 
- Increased willingness to publicly pledge to reduce their driving
- Increased willingness to influence others 
- Increased support for a more stringent CAZ policy

These two hypotheses will be further qualified by the following two way interactions.

H3: We anticipate that retributive framing (vs compensatory) of the clean air zone cost will have the following effects in the collective but not individualist condition:
- decrease in intended future car use
- increased intention to upgrade their vehicle 
- Increased willingness to publicly pledge to reduce their driving
- Increased willingness to influence others 
- Increased support for a more stringent CAZ policy
Furthermore, we expect that this effect of retributive framing on these 6 dependent variables will be mediated by participants' perceptions of the morality of driving in the CAZ, but only for those in the collective condition (i.e. a moderated mediation). 

H4: We anticipate that presenting participants with an artists' impression of the entry to the CAZ that depicts a red marking on the road (as opposed to a road with no physical markings) will have the following effects in the collective but not individualist condition:
- Decreased intended future car use
- Increased moralisation of the CAZ
- Increased intention to upgrade their vehicle 
- Increased willingness to publicly pledge to reduce their driving
- Increased willingness to influence others 
- Increased support for a more stringent CAZ policy
Furthermore, we expect that this effect of physical markings on the road on these 6 dependent variables will be mediated by participants' perceptions of the morality of driving in the CAZ, but only for those in the collective condition (i.e. a moderated mediation).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Randomised independent groups survey design with eight cells divided according to framing of the surcharge, the collectivity of language and whether or not there is a visual line demarcating the zone:
- Retributive and individualist framing (no line in image)
- Retributive and collectivist framing (no line in image)
- Retributive and individualist framing (line in image)
- Retributive and collectivist framing (line in image)
- Compensatory and individualist framing  (line in image)
- Compensatory and collectivist framing (line in image)
- Compensatory and individualist framing (no line in image)
- Compensatory and collectivist framing (no line in image)

q9.value: We utilise Qualtrics inbuilt randomisation function to randomly assign participants to one of eight conditions.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Data collection has started on Qualtrics, but the survey has not yet been closed and the complete data file not yet downloaded.  We have observed descriptive statistics relating to demographics variables within Qualtrics during data collection, simply for the purposes of trying to achieve a representative sample of the Bath population (via targeted advertising of the study, e.g. on social media).

question.value:
Participants will be recruited online with Facebook advertisements, flyers posted in home letterboxes and official Bath and Northeast Somerset council email circular communications. 
6 £250 gift cards were offered as a prize draw as an incentive for people to participate.

q13.value: We aim to recruit at least 1524 participants.

q14.value:
In order to be able to report descriptive response (‘polling’) data to our funder (Bath and Northeast Somerset Council), we determined a minimum sample size that would allow us to report these survey results as being representative of the population of Bath and Northeast Somerset council area (192,000 people), at 95% confidence level with a minimum confidence interval of 2.5 points. Using the macro calculator tool on https://www.surveysystem.com/sscalc.htm we determined that we needed a minimum sample size of 1524.

Through g*power, we calculated that this sample size of 1524 at 95% power would allow us to detect a small effect size of 0.093 at the standard .05 alpha probability. 

Due to time constraints, the survey will be closed no later than Wednesday 15th January 2020, and the maximum number of participants recruited up until that point will be analysed.

q15.value: Due to time constraints, the survey will be closed no later than Wednesday 15th January 2020, and the maximum number of participants recruited up until that point will be analysed.

question.value: The framing of the Clean Air Zone policy will be manipulated according to individualist/collectivist emphasis (i.e. yours/ours respectively) and compensatory/retributory framing of the fines (i.e. surcharge vs fine), and either the presence/absence of a line demarcating the zone. Full details of the framing can be found in the attached CAZ_Frames and Images pdf.

Travel Habits and Clean Air Zone Knowledge:
1. Current Transport Use of Bus/Car/Taxi/Walking/Bicycle/Park and Ride/Train/Electric-bike/Car sharing_car club/other (Seven item Likert scales ranging from Never- Everyday)
2. CAZ awareness- (have you been made aware- yes/no/not sure; do you drive a vehicle that will be charged- yes/no/not sure)

Moral Items (all measured on a seven-point likert scale from strongly disagree-strongly agree)
1.I feel personally responsible for limiting how often I will drive through the clean air zone
2. It would be socially unacceptable to choose to drive in the clean air zone
3. People have a responsibility to avoid driving in the Clean Air Zone
4. People shouldn't have to feel guilty if they use a car in the Clean Air Zone
5. Continuing to drive in the Clean Air Zone wouldn't really cause any harm
6. If you would like to further explain your answers for these questions above, you are welcome to provide more information below (Free-response)

DVs
1. How often do you intend to use the following modes of transport to travel to and around Bath city centre following the implementation of the Clean Air Zone? (Measures on a five-point likert from never-always)- Car/walking/taxi/park and ride/bus/car sharing or car club/bicycle/e-bike/other
2. Do you own a vehicle- yes/no
3. How likely would you be to consider upgrading your vehicle in the future to reduce its negative impact on air quality? (measured on seven point likert scale from very unlikely-very likely). 
4. Indicate your level of support for the above scheme (seven point likert from completely oppose to completely support)
5. If you would like to further explain your answer you are welcome to below (free response)
6. Stringency of the scheme - Does the scheme go too far, or not far enough (10 point slider scale from 'not far enough' to 'it goes too far')
7. How much would you support the scheme if private cars would not be automatically exempt from? (measured on seven-point likert scale from completely oppose to completely support)
8. If you'd like to explain your answer provide additional information below (free-response)
9. How likely would you be to encourage other people you know to drive less in Bath City Centre? (measured on seven point likert scale from very unlikely-very likely). 
10.  How willing would you be to sign a pledge as a commitment to trying to limit the amount you drive in Bath City Centre (measured on seven point likert scale from very unlikely-very likely). 
11. I feel personally affected by air pollution (measured on seven point likert scale from strongly disagree-strongly agree)
12. Air pollution is currently seen as an important issue by people who live in and around Bath (measured on seven point likert scale from strongly disagree-strongly agree)
13.  Air pollution is becoming an increasingly important issue for people who live in and around Bath. 

Demographics:
1. Age
2. Gender (Male/Female/Non-Binary/Other)
3. Highest qualification
4. Current primary employment status
5. Do you have a physical and/or mental health condition? (yes, provide details/no)
6. Any dependent children
7. What kind of vehicle do you own (car/van/motorbike/other)
8.  What type of engine does your vehicle have?
9. What is your current salary?
10. Political alignment (10 point sliding scale from extreme left- extreme right)
11. Environmental Identity scale
a) Acting in an environmentally friendly way is an important part of who I am (7 point likert scale from totally disagree-totally agree)
11. b) I am the type of person who acts in an environmentally friendly way (7 point likert scale from totally disagree-totally agree)
11. c) I see myself as an environmentally friendly person (7 point likert scale from totally disagree-totally agree)
12. Full postcode
13. Bath resident identity (items on (7 point likert scale from totally disagree-totally agree)
13a. I am not usually conscious of the fact I am a Bath resident
13b. I often regret that I am a Bath resident
13c. I don't feel a sense of being "connected" with other people who are Bath residents
13d. I have a lot in common with other people who are Bath residents
13e. Being a Bath resident is an important reflection of who I am
13f. In general, I'm glad to be a Bath resident
14. Transport Identities- categorical tickboxes (pedestrian/biker/commuter/cyclist/driver/motorist/public transport user/walker/ trucker or truck driver/ other/none of the above)
15. How long have you lived in Bath? (8 increments from 'I do not' to 'all my life' 
16. How did you hear about this survey
17. Any other comments? (free-response)
Scale measures will be combined into a scale mean, with reverse-scored items adjusted accordingly to make this possible.

H1 and H2: We will use a between participants two-way ANOVA for each of the 6 DVs.

H3: We will run a separate  2 x 2 ANOVA for each of the 6 DVs. In each case, both factors (fine frame; collectivity of wording) manipulated between-participant to test for the interaction. We will then test for the moderated mediation using the Alan Hayes PROCESS macro

H4: We will run a separate 2 x 2 ANOVA for each of the 6 DVs. In each case, both factors (physical demarcation; collectivity of wording) manipulated between-participant to test for the interaction. We will then test for the moderated mediation using the Alan Hayes PROCESS macro

q21.value: We will use the standard p value .05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value:
Exclusion criteria are as follows:
- Participants must live within the wider geographic area of Bath. Participants outside of this area will be excluded.
- To ensure participants have read the stimulus text, all participants who stay on the description screen for less than 15 seconds will be excluded.
- When analysing the car use intentions dependent variable, individuals who don't own their own car will be excluded.

q23.value: If a subject does not complete any of the DV questions, they will be excluded from the inferential analysis of the DV.

q24.value:
We will also conduct exploratory analyses to see whether the effects of our three IVs on our DVs might be potentially moderated by a range of demographic variables, such as: transport identity, bath resident identity, gender, age, income,  current transport behaviour and whether participants were under the impression at the start of the survey that their vehicle could be charged under the CAZ scheme.

We will also analyse the free-response questions qualitatively and quantitatively using LIWC to examine the differing moral language people use when contesting the clean air zone implementation. This will again be explored using demographic intersections.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Controversial events related to China have been in the media spotlight as China becomes a rising power in the past decade. At the international level, China was involved in territorial disputes with its neighboring countries in Asia, as well as a trade war with the United States. In terms of domestic politics, the country has experienced some illiberal changes – the government has rolled out a mass surveillance apparatus both online and offline, and there are increasing concerns over the human rights of ethnic minorities in the country. In light of recent events related to China, it is worth studying what citizens within China think of the path that the country has taken, as well as the intensity of their preferences. Our research uses a conjoint design to explicitly measure citizens’ intensity in, and trade-off among several policy domains in China.

q16.value: (H1) An average Chinese respondent exhibits single-peaked preferences in all four policy domains. (H2) Preference intensity of Chinese respondents varies across policy domains. For example, they may be more sensitive to the government’s policy position in the nationalism domain than the freedom of speech domain. (H2a) An average Chinese citizen is more sensitive to security and nationalism than freedom of speech. (H2b) An average Chinese citizen is more sensitive to security and nationalism than market economy. (H3) Preferences intensity revealed by the conjoint experiment is consistent with the relative importance of the policy domains stated by respondents prior to the conjoint experiment. (H4) Preferences revealed by the conjoint experiment are consistent with respondents’ answers to direct survey questions. For example, those who answer directly that they prefer a particular policy position exhibit a larger Average Marginal Component Effect (AMCE) for the exact position in the conjoint experiment. (H5) Preference intensity varies by respondents’ characteristics. We will explore heterogeneity in preference intensity across groups using pre-treatment covariates such as education and socio-economic status, measures of ideology, measures of nationalism and patriotism, regime support, media consumption, and political knowledge. (H6) Respondents’ tendency to prefer (what is perceived to be) the status quo policies is correlated with pre-treatment measures such as regime support. Those who declare stronger support for the regime or possess more likely to prefer policies that are close to the (self-perceived) status quo.

q17.value: Standard practice in conjoint experiments as recommended by Hainmueller, Hopkins, and Yamamoto (2013), and Leeper, Hobolt, and Tilley (2019).

attributes.title: GAN Faces: the behavioral consequences of observing a non-existing person
attributes.description: In this project, we want to investigate if people behave differently when seeing faces of non-existing people (artificially generated faces)

q1.value: The behavioural consequences of observing a non-existing person.

q2.value: Raffaele Tucciarelli, Neza Vehar, Manos Tsakiris

q3.value:
In a previous experiment (https://osf.io/9t3sy/?view_only=1a8571ac567b489ea19728c563c2c14c), we showed that artificially generated images depicting non-existing people (GAN faces) were rated more real than actually existing people (REAL faces).  Here, we intend to investigate the behavioural consequences of this bias. More specifically, we want to investigate the level of conformity elicited by the two types of stimuli. 
Previous studies showed that conformity (i.e. the over-proportional bias to match or copy an informational source, relative to random copying) can be experimentally manipulated. For example, conformity increases if the counterpart involved in the experiment is perceived as part of the in-group (Castelli, Vanzetto, Sherman, & Arcuri, 2001) or if the self-other boundaries are experimentally reduced using the enfacement task (Paladino, Mazzurega, Pavani, & Schubert, 2010).
Here we want to investigate if the different stimulus type (GAN vs REAL) will also elicit different levels of conformity within the same participants. In other words, will participants conform more to non-existing people than to real people?

q4.value: The amount of conformity will be different for the two stimulus types. Based on the previous results in which GAN images were rated as more real than REAL images, we predict that the conformity level will be higher for the GAN images.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We will employ a repeated-measures design to measure conformity. Conformity will be measured using a similar approach as used in Castelli et al., 2001: at each trial, participants will see one of the faces (either GAN or REAL) followed by an array of 200 letters organized in a random spatial configuration. Critically, the spatial density of the letter array will be manipulated at each trial giving the illusion that the number of the letters also varies (Anobile et al, 2014). The task of the participants will be to provide an estimation of the number of letters. Above the letter array, a number would indicate the estimation provided by the previously presented person. Importantly, this number will be randomly sampled from a normal distribution and therefore will not be informative of the actual number of letters in the display (which is fixed anyway). To ensure participants’ engagement in the task, we will inform them that the real faces did their best to provide an accurate estimation of the array display, whereas the estimates provided by the artificial faces were randomly generated by an algorithm. In this way, people will be motivated to conforming to the faces that they believe are real. Note that participants do not know which ones are the REAL or the GAN faces.
 
References
Anobile, G., Cicchini, G. M., & Burr, D. C. (2014). Separate Mechanisms for Perception of Numerosity and Density. Psychological Science, 25(1), 265–270. https://doi.org/10.1177/0956797613501520
Castelli, L., Vanzetto, K., Sherman, S. J., & Arcuri, L. (2001). The Explicit and Implicit Perception of In-Group Members Who Use Stereotypes: Blatant Rejection but Subtle Conformity. Journal of Experimental Social Psychology, 37(5), 419–426. https://doi.org/10.1006/jesp.2000.1471

q9.value: For each participant, we will present all images in the same session, meaning that each type of image (either REAL or GAN) followed by a letter array will be presented in an event-related fashion. The order of the stimulus presentation will be randomized by Gorilla (Gorilla.sc), no further constraints will be used.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: We have previously collected data as a pilot (N=20 naïve participants) to evaluate the script and the average duration of the experiment. No further analyses were conducted.

question.value:
This will be a follow-up experiment and we aim at testing those participants that took part in our previous study ( https://osf.io/9t3sy/?view_only=1a8571ac567b489ea19728c563c2c14c) and passed the attention checks. More specifically, participants of the previous study will be contacted via the Prolific Academic platform and asked if they willing to participate in the follow-up study.

If we won’t be able to recruit enough participants from the previous study (see the Sample size section), we will recruit new participants.

Participants will be paid £8/hr. We estimated that the experiment should be concluded in 32 minutes on average, so we intend to pay participants 4.27£. Participants will be recruited from UK and EU countries. To further motivate participants, we will instruct them that we will check one random trial and if their response is sufficiently close to the real number (within 5% error), we will grant them a bonus (0.50£). Note that, for the nature of the task, it is unlikely that participants will be actually able to reach such a performance in any of the trials, therefore we will grant the bonus to all participants independently of their responses.

q13.value: We are planning to collect at least N=60 up to N=116 participants. This number will depend on the number of people that will be willing to participate in the follow-up study.

q14.value: Ideally, we would like to test all the 116 participants that participated in the first experiment. As we believe it is unlikely everybody will respond to our invitation, we expect a smaller sample. Previous studies using a similar approach used different sample sizes: Castelli et al., 2001 (study 1; N=96); Vaes et al., 2002 (study 2; N=60); and Paladino et al., 2010 (N=16). We think 16 participants would be too small, so we hope to at least get up to N=60 participants and ideally up to N=96. If we won’t be able to get a sufficient number of participants (N=60), we will start recruiting naïve participants.

question.value: The stimulus type (GAN vs REAL) will be randomly manipulated at each trial. Furthermore, the density of the following array letter will be varied at each trial sampling from a predefined density distribution. Finally, the anchor (the number on top of the letter array) will be sampled from a normal distribution. More information can be found in the OSF.io page of this project.
We will measure one variable of interest: the estimated number of the letters at each trial

Conformity Index (CI). The level of conformity will be estimated for the two types of stimuli (GAN vs REAL) as the mean distance between the anchor and the participant’s estimation (Castelli et al., 2001; Vaes et al., 2002). The lower bound of this index will be zero which will indicate the maximal level of conformity. Higher values of CI will indicate a lower level of conformity (as the distance from the anchors will be bigger, on average).

We are planning to run at least two types of analysis:
“Do GAN images elicit larger conformity (lower CI) than the REAL images?”
A paired T-test will be used to test the alternative hypothesis that the CI means of the two stimulus types (REAL Vs GAN) are different. 
As the images depict also different genders (equally distributed), a 2x2 within-subjects ANOVA with Stimulus Type (REAL vs GAN) and Image Gender (Male vs Female) as a factor. The CI will be used as the dependent variable.

q22.value:
We used the Gorilla Task Builder (Gorilla.sh) to present the stimuli and collect the data (Anwyl-Irvine, Massonnié, Flitton, Kirkham, & Evershed, 2019). To ensure that all participants will pay attention to the task, we added four catch trials. If participants miss more than one catch trial, they will be removed from data analysis. These excluded participants will not receive the reimbursement for their participation, as clearly stated in the consent agreement. Note that if we will end up below the minimum sample size (N=60) requirement after data exclusion, we will collect more participants to meet the predefined number. 
References
Anwyl-Irvine, A. L., Massonnié, J., Flitton, A., Kirkham, N., & Evershed, J. K. (2019). Gorilla in our midst: An online behavioral experiment builder. Behavior Research Methods. https://doi.org/10.3758/s13428-019-01237-x

q23.value: People will have 10 seconds to provide their answer. If after 10 seconds a response is not provided, the experiment will continue to the next trial. A few missing responses are expected and will be treated as null values. If more than 5% (5 trials) of responses will be missed, participants will be excluded from the analysis and will not receive the reimburse. This will be clearly stated in the consent form.

registration_responses.q2: Raffaele Tucciarelli, Neza Vehar, Manos Tsakiris
registration_responses.q3:
In a previous experiment (https://osf.io/9t3sy/?view_only=1a8571ac567b489ea19728c563c2c14c), we showed that artificially generated images depicting non-existing people (GAN faces) were rated more real than actually existing people (REAL faces).  Here, we intend to investigate the behavioural consequences of this bias. More specifically, we want to investigate the level of conformity elicited by the two types of stimuli. 
Previous studies showed that conformity (i.e. the over-proportional bias to match or copy an informational source, relative to random copying) can be experimentally manipulated. For example, conformity increases if the counterpart involved in the experiment is perceived as part of the in-group (Castelli, Vanzetto, Sherman, & Arcuri, 2001) or if the self-other boundaries are experimentally reduced using the enfacement task (Paladino, Mazzurega, Pavani, & Schubert, 2010).
Here we want to investigate if the different stimulus type (GAN vs REAL) will also elicit different levels of conformity within the same participants. In other words, will participants conform more to non-existing people than to real people?
